      Hoyt: Interview with Robert C. McFarlane. Mr. McFarlane was National Security Advisor from October, 1983 until November, 1985. Interviewer: Austin Hoyt - Thursday, June 6, 1996, Washington, D.C. McFarlane, Robert McFarlane, Robert National Security Advisor (United States) Hoyt, Austin Washington (inhabited place)

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Mr. McFarlane, how will Ronald Reagan be remembered? What's his important legacy? Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      McFarlane: I believe President Reagan will be a giant figure in history. For mostly, for his achieving what none of his predecessors had, the collapse of Marxism and the Soviet Union, the reduction of nuclear weapons, which neither Nixon nor Kissinger could achieve. He'll be remembered as a foreign policy President. Reagan, Ronald Marxism Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire) Nixon, Richard M. (Richard Milhous), 1913-1994 Kissinger, Henry, 1923-

      Watch this
      Hoyt: What's the most important misconception about him?

      Watch this
      McFarlane: the misconception of Reagan is in -- Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      -- I believe the characterization of Ronald Reagan as superficial is the leading myth. Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      He did focus on important things but he focused on them in enormous depth -- take Russia and-- Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire)

      Watch this
      -- before the Geneva Summit. I've never seen a President -- Nixon, Ford, Carter, absorb -- digest -- and master such a depth of information about the agenda and the other party, Gorbachev. Reagan was the master of that material and of that Summit. Geneva (inhabited place) Nixon, Richard M. (Richard Milhous), 1913-1994 Ford, Gerald R., 1913-2006 Carter, Jimmy, 1924- Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Hoyt: What do you think the source of his appeal was to the American people?

      Watch this
      McFarlane: I think the source of Ronald Reagan's appeal to Americans was his ability to inspire confidence, optimism, a sense that life is going to get better and that you can achieve great things if you work at it. Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Ah, I used to dismiss that dimension of being the President, and I used to think it was more important for Presidents to know substance -- how to solve a problem of housing or healthcare. But, just as important, and I think probably more so, is the ability to inspire confidence, hope, and Ronald Reagan could do that like no other President. Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Hoyt: How did his policies toward the Soviet Union differ from his predecessors? Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire)

      Watch this
      McFarlane: President Reagan's policies were dramatically different from all of his predecessors, with regard to the Soviet Union. Detent, for example, rested on the premise that although we, in(?) the Soviet Union, might disagree, there was no prospect that we could prevail -- that because the Soviets had so much wealth, and oil, and gas and metal, that their inefficient system could survive, just by living off capital. Reagan, Ronald Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire) Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire)

      Watch this
      But Ronald Reagan didn't believe that. Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      He believed a very different thing, that if you stressed the Soviet economy enough, you could bring it down. He also believed that, ah, to tolerate anything less, ah, was irresponsible, that we had an obligation to compete and that you didn't need to necessarily fear confrontation. And he was right about that.

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Did he want to win?

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Yes, he did.

      Watch this
      And, I say he wanted to win, not in the sense of, ah, a gesture of the cowboy or of swaggering. He genuinely believed that the Soviet system was an evil and that he had an obligation to try to relieve the suffering of the Russian people.

      Watch this
      Hoyt: How did he propose to do that?

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Ronald Reagan believed that if you stressed the Soviet economy enough by imposing burdens upon it, to spend beyond its capacity, that you could, in effect, add the last straw, that after 70 years, since 1917, even though they were struggling along, they were getting weaker, day by day, and his hope was to add the last straw, which he did. Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Hoyt: In general, was the defense built up?

      Watch this
      McFarlane: The defense build up was part of it. However, in parallel, Reagan stressed the Soviet economy by denying it income. For example, the Russians wanted to build a pipeline to sell gas in Europe, in 1982, which would have earned them about $2 billion a year. Reagan said, they'll only take that money and put it into missiles and weapons and we ought to insist that our European allies not do it. It had led to a very big argument with Margaret Thatcher and the German, French, Italians because they needed the gas. But, Reagan won the argument and denied the Russians $2 billion a year. And it was part of that last straw that broke the Marxist camel's back. Reagan, Ronald Reagan, Ronald Thatcher, Margaret Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Isn't it dangerous to poke the Russian bear in the eye?

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Well, Reagan was not a cowboy. And, with respect to the Soviet Union, he understood that it was risky to provoke any dictator, ah, disposed of so much power. But he relied upon people who [stutters] understood the Russian tolerance for provocation and criticism. And he moderated his comments when he needed to, to avoid pushing them over that threshold. Reagan, Ronald Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire)

      Watch this
      Hoyt: You wrote that you helped nudge the President to soften his views toward the Soviet Union. When was that, and why did you do it, and why did you think it was important to do it? Reagan, Ronald Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire)

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Well, I think our approach, my approach and George Shultz' was not to urge the President to change his mind about Marxism but to recognize that if he wanted to make this relationship more stable, that he had to, not just make peace in his time but record it in treaties, by limiting weapons, that would last beyond his administration. Shultz, George Pratt, 1920- Reagan, Ronald Marxism

      Watch this
      So, our point was you don't have to change your mind boss, but you should begin to talk to the Russians and create something that will last beyond your administration.

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Was this evidence resisted in the Pentagon? The Pentagon

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Well, the advice that the President ought to engage with the Russians, in the second term, Reagan really didn't resist that. In fact, I think he probably had a better sense of what it would take to succeed a negotiation with the Russians than many of his advisors. Reagan, Ronald Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Reagan's point was, in the first term, we're not going to be able to get their attention. It will take four years for us to present a credible, ah, adversary to the Russians again -- not only by the defense build up, but by the recovery of our economy, both of these demonstrating that we are a society in the U.S. that can solve its own problems. Reagan, Ronald United States (nation)

      Watch this
      But, after four years, Reagan thought yes, we will have gotten their attention and they will be ready and we will be ready to talk, and he did. In 1984, he allowed the, ah, Secretary of State to begin to write speeches and give speeches that offered, offered the Russians a chance to sit down and start talking. Reagan, Ronald Shultz, George Pratt, 1920-

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Were you around during the Freeze Movement and the tension over the deployment of the Pershings? Antinuclear movement MGM-31 Pershing

      Watch this
      McFarlane: The nuclear freeze movement, ah, began to gather momentum in the spring of 1982. I had been in the White House a few months and it gathered momentum through '92 or '80 - '82 and into the spring of '83 and, concurrently, the United States and our allies and NATO were trying to deploy cruise missiles and the Pershings, to counteract the Russian, ah, SS-20s. But yes, I was there at the time and, ah, SDI was part of the strategy to counter that, ah, movement. Antinuclear movement White House United States (nation) North Atlantic Treaty Organization MGM-31 Pershing SS-20 Missile Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      Hoyt: On the nuclear freeze movement, did he feel the pressure? Did he ever say anything to you about the freeze movement and the people participating in it? Antinuclear movement Antinuclear movement

      Watch this
      McFarlane: President Reagan, ah, received enormous criticism from the Freeze Movement that was sustained and very sharp over a period of months and months. Reagan, Ronald Antinuclear movement

      Watch this
      But, one of the, ah, striking qualities of Reagan was that he could deal with criticism far better than any President I've worked with, because of his conviction and his-- his comfort with himself that his place in history, his obligation to the people was secure, and that he was right and, ah-- Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      -- his sense of self confidence about being right and opposing the Freeze Movement gave him a piece of mind that was quite, ah, unusual. Antinuclear movement

      Watch this
      Hoyt: You weren't around when the Korean airliner was shot down, were you? You came on the National Security, became the overseas advisor a month later. Korean Air Lines Incident, 1983

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Oh, I had been the Deputy National Security Advisor from '82 through '83. However, I had been detailed as the successor to Phil Habib in the me when that happened. And so, I'd been out of the White House for about two months. Deputy National Security Advisor Habib, Philip Charles, 1920- White House

      Watch this
      Hoyt: But it seems to me, when you read the accounts, it was a very tense time, that period, in the Fall of '83, after the Korean airliner was shot down, with all the pressure to prevent deployment, and then the Soviets walking out of the Geneva talks another time. What was your sense of the time? Did you sense it was being -- you've been involved in security issues for many years, did you sense it was a particularly tense time, in America's relation with the Russians? Korean Air Lines Incident, 1983 Geneva (inhabited place)

      Watch this
      McFarlane: The period from the summer of '83through the Fall was a period which, ah, has been characterized, as very tense between ourselves and the Russians.

      Watch this
      And it is fair to say that it was more tense than other periods.

      Watch this
      However, I didn't then or now believe that it was near the crisis point.

      Watch this
      It seemed to me that such of the anxiety being heard from our friends in London, Germany, France was sewn by Russian dis-information, portraying us, Reagan as cowboys, ah, dangerous and so forth. But that was rhetoric, ah, good propaganda from the Kremlin, but it wasn't really reliant upon facts of real tension. London (inhabited place) Germany (nation) France (nation) Reagan, Ronald Kremlin (Moscow, Russia)

      Watch this
      And, in fact, the shoot down of the 007 Korean airliner -- ah, if you're sitting in the Kremlin and you watch that happen, if anything, it makes the Kremlin less likely to do something, vis-à-vis, the United States. You just had a demonstration that your own ability to command your own forces is very shaky. Well, the last thing you want to do is take on somebody like the United States. Korean Air Lines Incident, 1983 Kremlin (Moscow, Russia) Kremlin (Moscow, Russia) United States (nation) United States (nation)

      Watch this
      Hoyt: In March 23rd of 1983 when the strategic defense initiative was announced on television, that had been prepared in secret. But why the secrecy and the surprise? Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      McFarlane: The SDI Program was prepared in secrecy, and I believe it was the right course now. I certain -- Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      Hoyt: You didn't at the time?

      Watch this
      McFarlane: No, but I believe the President was right in wanting to keep it a secret, because, as he said, any time that you want to take the country in a fundamentally different direction from what course it is on, you are bound to evoke criticism, even from your own administration, from the State Department, from those who like the status quo. And that criticism will undermine your new idea before it ever gets off the ground. Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      It would have undermined Nixon's overture to China, he believed, had Nixon made it a normal part of bureaucratic policy development. But, he believed that he had to launch that secretly, and that the merit of the idea, its appeal to Americans, would engender its own constituency that would outflank that criticism by the Congress or the press. Nixon, Richard M. (Richard Milhous), 1913-1994 China (nation) Nixon, Richard M. (Richard Milhous), 1913-1994

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Wasn't this really unsettling, though, for good reasons to the arms control community and our NATO allies? North Atlantic Treaty Organization

      Watch this
      McFarlane: The SDI initiative was very unsettling to our allies and certainly to the Russians, to many in the Congress. But, of course, dramatic ideas of inspiration are often, ah, alarming -- the zero option, proposing to do away with ballistic missiles, all of these unorthodox ideas of Ronald Reagan's today in the hindsight, ah, have been proven to be very sound. Strategic Defense Initiative Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Hoyt: What was your interest in SDI? Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      McFarlane: SDI seemed to me to be a way in which we could change the competition with the Russians. Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      Up until that time, we had been trying roughly to maintain a balance -- plane for plane, tank for tank, which really plays to Russian advantage. They don't have a Congress -- they can build always more than we can. We ought to be investing, I thought at the time, in what we do best, what gives us a comparative advantage and that's high technology. So, for me, it was an investment strategy.

      Watch this
      I thought that if we could invest dollar, a dollar in high technology, it would require the Russians to spend more than a dollar to deal with it. In short, it was a way to stress the Russian economy to our advantage.

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Did you see it as a bargaining chip?

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Not per se.

      Watch this
      In my judgment, ah, we would not need to build SDI because its effect would be for the Russians to come, asking us how to stop it. And then, in turn, they would end up reducing their nuclear weapons. And, at that point, we wouldn't need to build SDI. But, I believed, in any event, that we ought to be conducing that R&D, research and development program, so that we would be able to defend against ballistic missiles, some day, in other countries. Strategic Defense Initiative Nuclear weapons Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      Hoyt: What was the President's interest in it? Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      McFarlane: President Reagan believed that the strategic defense initiatives or Star Wars, was really an expression of moral responsibility. Reagan, Ronald Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      He didn't believe in the balance of terror and believed that he had an obligation to try to physically defend Americans against the attack of the Russian missiles, [sigh], but the concept of deterrence was not a stable concept.

      Watch this
      Hoyt: How did he measure it with work -- to throw a switch and he'd have a shield, or what was -- Did he think about that?

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Well, he did-- Ah, President Reagan had no illusions that SDI could be built in a day or a month or a year. But you never achieve anything of greatness if you don't start, and he believed that we had to start, or we would face the day of nuclear catastrophe. Reagan, Ronald Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Did you ever hear Ronald Reagan talk about Armageddon? Reagan, Ronald Armageddon

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Yes, the President had, ah, given a lot of thought to the scriptural foreshadowing of Armageddon. And he believed that it could occur in his lifetime, and that the instrument of all our destruction could be a nuclear war between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. Reagan, Ronald Armageddon United States (nation) Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire)

      Watch this
      That fear was what drove him so passionately to try to move us away from the strategy that relied on our ability to threaten the Soviet Union and toward a strategy that didn't rely so much on offense, but on defense. And he has been proven correct. Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire)

      Watch this
      Hoyt: When we talked on the phone a few weeks ago, you told us what he said about the scriptures. Can you remember that?

      [BACKGROUND DISCUSSION]

      Watch this
      McFarlane: The phenomenal risk presented by two opposing nuclear super powers was a condition the President had given a lot of thought to. Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      His fear was inspired really by his reading of the scriptures which, in his judgment, stressed that man could sow the seeds of his own destruction, and that that human failing, in our generation, was expressed by this nuclear standoff, where we and the Soviets were threatening each other with this huge offensive nuclear arsenal to blow each other away. And, the President believed that it could get out of control, and he felt an enormous personal obligation to move us away from that threat of nuclear war. Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Hoyt: When he talked about this could happen in our lifetime, describe how he looked. Did he get anguish?

      Watch this
      McFarlane: President Reagan clearly looked at this balance of terror as-- as, ah, with genuine anguish. When he talked about it, you could see that it was a genuine fare, and it caused him to speak much more measurable, and to, ah, withdraw physically into himself, and to, oh, make very evident the passion with which he felt he must move us away from this condition of threatening each other's destruction. And he did. Reagan, Ronald

      [BACKGROUND DISCUSSION]

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Can you remember a particular moment --

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Several times in the Oval Office, when I would be briefing the President, he would stop to -- Oval Office Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      -- More than once, President Reagan, in the Oval Office, expressed how he felt about this balance of terror. Reagan, Ronald Oval Office

      Watch this
      And I remember very well how, each time, he would be genuinely anguished, and would physically withdraw and lean forward and, ah, with quite passion, oh, explain his fear that Armageddon was at hand. And, that unless he tried to move us away from this incredible nuclear threat of each other, that it could happen in his lifetime. And he was determined to do something about it. Armageddon

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Let's talk about Geneva. How did you prepare him for it? Geneva (inhabited place)

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Once the announcement was agreed upon, for Gorbachev and Reagan to meet at the Summit in Geneva, President Reagan, ah, devoted his time and energy to a very thorough study of -- of Russia, and to support that we delivered, about once a week, a very detailed paper that would go over, ah, each week, a different aspect important to U.S./Soviet relations, the role of the KGB, the role of the Communist Party, the personality and background of Gorbachev, Soviet negotiation style, tactics, strategy, relationship between ballistic missiles and Soviet adventurism in third world countries. Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Reagan, Ronald Geneva (inhabited place) Reagan, Ronald Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire) KGB Communist party Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931-

      Watch this
      But, each week, one of these papers would go to him on Monday, he would clearly read it, ask very penetrating questions about it. but the effect was, after 2 or 30 of these papers, to have given him a grasp of his agenda and of his adversary better than any President, in my recollection.

      Watch this
      Hoyt: You read Jim Baker was disappointed because he didn't read his briefing books at the Summit because the Sound of Music was on the air. And other people say that he just couldn't handle conceptual thought or analytical thinking, so they had to have drawings and movies for him. You gave him things that were written in conceptual language, and he read them and understood them. Baker, James Addison, 1930-

      Watch this
      McFarlane: One of the myths about Ronald Reagan is that he was superficial and wouldn't read his briefing books or take seriously the agenda, whether it was the Williamsburg Summit or the G7 or trade or whatever it might be. And, I think it is a myth, and I say that because what is true, is that Reagan, Ronald Williamsburg Economic Summit (1983)

      Watch this
      Ronald Reagan had a sense of what was truly important. And when you lay out in the 1980s what was really important, in the way of foreign affairs, it was dealing with the Soviet Union and reducing tensions. Reagan cared about that, and because he cared about it, he put a lot of time and effort into understanding how to deal with the Russians. And he mastered that brief, better than any President, certainly better than Nixon. Reagan, Ronald Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire) Reagan, Ronald Nixon, Richard M. (Richard Milhous), 1913-1994

      Watch this
      And, so when you say that Reagan was indifferent, that went asleep at the Williamsburg Summit, so would it. It was a bore -- nothing important was going to happen there. But, when it came to the Soviet Union, Ronald Reagan was on top of the brief, better than Gorbachev, better than any other American President to engage with him. Reagan, Ronald Williamsburg Economic Summit (1983) Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire) Reagan, Ronald Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931-

      Watch this
      Hoyt: What was the decision about the overcoat that first day -- that was before he met Gorbachev. Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931-

      Watch this
      McFarlane: Gosh, I'm not sure I even remembered that. I don't honestly believe that it was a-- a kind of premeditated, ah, extended, ah, matter for Ronald Reagan. I think if anything, Mike Deaver might have, ah, thought there was some psychological advantage to be gained by the President, ah, not having an overcoat on. And, but for Ronald Reagan, I don't recall this as a terribly important matter. Reagan, Ronald Deaver, Michael K. Reagan, Ronald Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Tell us about his performance, what you observed in his discussions with Gorbachev. Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931-

      Watch this
      McFarlane: [stutter] Ronald Reagan's meetings with Gorbachev in Geneva, in '85 truly deserved to be recorded as -- as a high water mark of American diplomacy. Reagan, Ronald Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Geneva (inhabited place)

      Watch this
      There were three meetings on the first day. The first one was one-on-one, that is, Reagan, Gorbachev, no one else, except interpreters. And in that session, of about 45 minutes-- Reagan, Ronald Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931-

      Watch this
      -- Gorbachev came at Reagan very hard, with a very severe and intellectually quite crisp criticism of SDI. Reagan came back at him with a very thoughtful, well organized brief on why we worry about the Soviet Union and aggression, why they need not worry about us. At any rate, Gorbachev and Reagan came to the second meeting with all of the staffs. Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Reagan, Ronald Strategic Defense Initiative Reagan, Ronald Soviet Union (former nation/state/empire) Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      But again, Gorbachev started off with this intellectually persuasive argument against SDI. And, you could see, as he was talking Reagan kind of gathered enthusiasm, and adrenaline started(?) pumping, and he'd need to get ready. And he answered with his won 20 minute rebuttal of what Gorbachev had said, and a very effective, pressing of the case for SDI and why the Russians need not worry about it. Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Strategic Defense Initiative Reagan, Ronald Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      Well, that basic agenda item on SDI led to a point, counterpoint between the two for an hour and a half. and Gorbachev believed that he was making arguments that were sound, logical, they involved pointing out the risks technology, cost-wise and so forth. Strategic Defense Initiative Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931-

      Watch this
      But, at the end of it, after he had tried on an one-on-one session and tried three times in the preliminary session, Gorbachev could see that he wasn't getting anywhere. But Reagan was determined that he was not going to let go of this program. Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      And it seemed to me, in retrospect, that Gorbachev must have weighed, taken the measure of Ronald Reagan at that point, estimated his political power and ability to fund the SDI program and get Margaret Thatcher and the Congress and the American people to go along with it, but it was a point-- Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Reagan, Ronald Strategic Defense Initiative Thatcher, Margaret

      Watch this
      -- about an hour and a half into that session, where when he was not getting anywhere, suddenly Gorbachev seemed to lose all of the air inside him. He physically slumped and he looked very hard at Reagan, he shook his head, and he said I don't agree with anything you're saying. I think you're wrong, but I'll reconsider -- it was a turning point. Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Hoyt: Were you proud of the President? Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Were you disappointed that Reagan stuck to his guns or were you -- I mean, do you think he had an opportunity to bargain away SDI for cuts in other areas? Reagan, Ronald Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      McFarlane: I could not have been more pleased with the way in which President Reagan simply dismissed Gorbachev's arguments and defended the SDI program, because, in fact, it led to exactly what we all wanted. Reagan, Ronald Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Strategic Defense Initiative

      Watch this
      Hoyt: But you didn't know that -- at that time, did you think we're losing and opportunity to, Gorbachev was so concerned about it, to say well what's it worth to you. Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931-

      Watch this
      McFarlane: At the very beginning, when the SDI program was launched, in my judgment, its potential would either be proven or disproven within four or five years. And the moment at which you would be able to judge whether it was working or not, is when or if, Gorbachev ever made it clear that he knew he wasn't going to win, that he could not out-negotiate Ronald Reagan and that really happened, at the Geneva Summit. And all of us could not have been more proud of President Reagan. Ah, Gorbachev blinked. And, while it wasn't consummated until the Treaty was signed three years later, the turning point was in Geneva, in '85. Strategic Defense Initiative Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Reagan, Ronald Geneva (inhabited place) Reagan, Ronald Gorbachev, Mikhail Sergeevich, 1931- Geneva (inhabited place)

      Watch this
      Hoyt: How did the White House operation change in the second term, when Don Regan came in as Chief of Staff? White House White House Chief of Staff

      Watch this
      McFarlane: The functioning of the White House staff, under Jim Baker, through the first time, had been a very collegial one. Jim saw his role as being both, ah, an administrator manager, but also a political filter. And he played both roles extremely well. He recognized that many on the staff had specialties in national security or economics, and that they ought to be given their access to the President. That changed in the second term. White House Baker, James Addison, 1930- Baker, James Addison, 1930- Reagan, Ronald

      Watch this
      Don Regan saw himself as more of a prime minister, that is a -- a policy official whose judgment and knowledge about economics, national security, healthcare, housing, whatever, justified his pronouncement on any of these policies. Jim Baker would not have done that. he might have had an opinion, but Don Regan was more intrusive and to the policy process. Baker, James Addison, 1930-

      Watch this
      Hoyt: In all your experience with White House operations, is it customary for the Chief of Staff to be aware of or have control of the National Security Advisor? Or do they operate independent? White House National Security Advisor (United States)

      Watch this
      McFarlane: No, the relationship between the Chief of Staff and the National Security Advisor is, ah, a sensitive one, because there are certain matters in which the President and his advisor have to deal directly. Normally, the Chief of Staff certainly ought to be informed about everything. However, a wise Chief of Staff recognizes those very few occasions where he doesn't have a need to know. And Jim Baker handled that very well. Historically, most White House Chiefs of Staff have, and most National Security Advisors have seen the wisdom of not trying to go around the Chief of Staff, except of very, very, very rare occasions. Reagan, Ronald Baker, James Addison, 1930- White House Chief of Staff National Security Advisor (United States)

      Watch this
      Hoyt: In the Contra business, should Don Regan have known what was going on? How did this problem come to be? Iran-Contra Affair, 1985-1990

      Watch this
